posts.name: Hale Talons 554
posts.cooked:
Hello teams,  We are reaching out to try to see if a team can help us get to the next level with programming. We may make it to States based on doing Ok at our other events, so we are trying to get a few extras sorted out so we can be even more helpful if we make it. We have zero coding experience and rely a lot on the net and you guys to help us get the basics, but if we could get a little help with a few things that would be great. I have included our Git repository for you to look at. You will see it is quite simple. That being said we have a small wish list. We are capable of changing numbers and dialing things if we just need the basic outline written for us. The list is below along with the GIT for our simple functions. We have a lot to learn for sure, but this would help us if we make the show.  Everyone who has helped so far,thank you.

Auton that moves the wrist up for “?” of seconds at “?” power, holds that motor, drives forward for “?” seconds at “?” power, stops, spins coral intake (out) for “?” seconds, stops, This would put one on in auton, either the low post or trough. We can tune and build from there. We know this is a sequential group; it just fails when we try to set it up.

Auton that moves the wrist up for “?” of seconds at “?” power, holds that motor, drives forward for “?” seconds at “?” power, stops, spins coral intake (out) for “?” seconds, stops, This would put one on in auton, either the low post or trough. We can tune and build from there. We know this is a sequential group; it just fails when we try to set it up.

A webcam, so we can be 100 on our placement.

A webcam, so we can be 100 on our placement.

GIT  for simple https://github.com/joecoleman/Team5547-main.git

posts.name: Hale Talons 554
posts.cooked: anyone??

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked: Do you have an example of your attempts with a sequential group? It sounds like you could use a WPIlib timer to do some of these functions. If you create a timer in your command, reset it in the initialize function, and check it in the “isfinished” method, then you can run a command for a set amount of time. It looks like you don’t run feedback control on your subsystems, so you would probably run your elevator up for a certain amount of time and then drive for a certain amount of time. I can help with code if this is still confusing.

posts.name: Jim Sokoloff
posts.cooked:
The webcam you can just plug into the Rio’s USB and show it on your dashboard with one line of Java code and some configuration. Directions here .

For the autonomous, I’d strongly recommend that you incorporate sensor-based feedback into all of the positioning items that you mention. Don’t turn the arm for X milliseconds at Y power, but instead turn it until the encoder (probably built into the motor and controller you’re using) increments by Z counts.

Time-based can work in theory, but it’s extremely fiddly and has low repeatability as compared to closed-loop control processes.

link_counts.title: Using the CameraServer on the roboRIO — FIRST Robotics Competition documentation

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked: Agreed on using feedback being better. It looks like you are using brushless motors on Spark Maxes, so I’m assuming they’re NEOs. The NEO motors have built in encoders. If you power on at consistent positions, then you can move the motor to a target position and use the encoder value as your setpoint, achieving a specific position instead of moving blindly. Instead of running on a timer, you can run until your arm is within a small error of this setpoint.

posts.name: Hale Talons 554
posts.cooked: So I pushed in the webcam(i think) . Could you put that together for us. That is our struggle. We don’t even know what that would look like. We can make adjustments but what and where to add it would be the biggest help.

posts.name: Hale Talons 554
posts.cooked: Please if you can maybe branch our code and show us what that would look like. We can make adjustment from there. We just want more option then we have now.

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked:
How precise does your arm height need to be? I am at school right now but if you haven’t made more progress by the time I get home I will try to help.

For a starting point, you access the encoder through sparkMaxName.getEncoder().

The rotations come from the .get() method.

The simplest way would be to just run your mechanism positively until it exceeds the setpoint and then stop it. Your logic in the IsFinished part of the command would be something like return encoderValue > targetRotations, and you should run the motor in your execute block and stop it in the end block.

Someone else might suggest more fine tuning with a proportional feedback controller, which I would be happy to try to support you through, but if you don’t need much precision then this should work.

posts.name: Hale Talons 554
posts.cooked: We will do precision next year. We need close, and if it fails it will make the trough at least. Right now we just go straight and don’t deliver anything.

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked: This code was written in the best IDE , ChiefDelphi, so it may have some missing semicolons or weird formatting or something. However, this is how I would go about it. You will need to find your setpoints and create a method to get the rotations of the wrist. Please make sure you read through and try to understand it so you can implement similar logic in the future, or move up to precision and using proper feedback control, as this is purely moving until the setpoint and not moving based on your distance from your setpoint.

posts.name: Hale Talons 554
posts.cooked: I think I am following this, we need to create commands to do the work. After we do this how do we get it to do it in auton?

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked: You would sequence this command first, and then run a move command. You can do a similar thing to this for your movement, where you move until your wheel encoders have traveled a certain distance, or if you’re just lining up to the front of the reef you might have success with driving at a slow speed for a time. Sensor-based control will always be more reliable once you get it working though. Then you can sequence a command which runs your outtake, or uses this same paradigm to move to a new position, whatever your mechanism needs to score.

posts.name: Hale Talons 554
posts.cooked: Could you show us what that would look like and where to put it? I assume we need to add a coral eject command as well. Then work in robot container for the sequence?

posts.name: Kevin
posts.cooked:
You would run something like this: In robotContainer

.andThen() is how you can sequence commands in order (sequentially), and if I read your code right then you are already using the getAutonomousCommand method so this should be as simple as making the commands and then sequencing them in that return.
